abstract.text: A view that captures Apple Pencil input and displays the rendered results in an iOS app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object captures content drawn using Apple Pencil or the user’s finger and displays it in your app. The canvas view handles all of the touch events and data coming from Apple Pencil, and renders that information using the tool you specify. The canvas stores the captured input in a
is a scroll view, so you can make the drawable area bigger than the canvas view’s frame rectangle. To do that, set the inherited
property to the size you want. The canvas view automatically scales its underlying content to match the size you specify. Users scroll around the canvas using a two-finger pan gesture. (If the
, users scroll with only one finger.)
A canvas view conforms to the

protocol, so you can add it as an observer of the window’s tool picker. The tool picker displays a floating palette of tools that the user can choose from. As the user interacts with items in the palette, such as changing ink colors, or line widths, the canvas automatically updates its drawing environment accordingly.

abstract.text: The size of the content view.
Capture touch and Apple Pencil input as a drawing, and display that content from your app.
A view that captures Apple Pencil input and displays the rendered results in an iOS app.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the canvas accepts input from the user’s finger in addition to Apple Pencil.
The object you use to respond to changes in the drawn content or with the selected tool.
The data object that the canvas uses to store drawn content.
The gesture recognizer that the canvas uses to track touch events.
The policy that controls the types of touches allowed when drawing on the canvas.
A Boolean value that indicates whether a ruler view is visible on the canvas.
The maximum version of PencilKit to support.
The currently selected tool used for drawing.
The currently selected tool used for drawing.
Methods for monitoring drawing related changes in a canvas view.
Constants that you use to specify the type of drawing gestures your app permits while the user draws on the canvas.
A structure representing the drawing information captured by a canvas view.
A data structure that contains the drawing information captured by a canvas view.
A utility class that represents range components of a stroke.
A structure that represents an ink that specifies its type, color, and width.
Provides a description of the creation and rendering of marks on a canvas.
A structure that represents the paths, boundaries, and other properties of a stroke drawn on a canvas.
A structure that captures the components of a stroke and provides methods to find and interpolate points along the stroke’s path.
A class that captures the components of a stroke and provides methods to find and interpolate points along the stroke’s path.
A structure that represents the properties of a specific point along a stroke’s path.
A class that represents the properties of a specific point along a stroke’s path.
A class that represents the paths, boundaries and other properties of a stroke drawn on a canvas.
An interface you use to detect when the user changes the selected tools and drawing characteristics of a tool picker object.
Enable writing on a non-text-input view by adding interactions.
Add expressive, low-latency drawing to your app using PencilKit.
Score users’ ability to match PencilKit drawings generated from text, by accessing the strokes and points inside PencilKit drawings.

doc://com.apple.pencilkit/documentation/.title: Inspecting, Modifying, and Constructing PencilKit Drawings

abstract.text: Leverage the latest PencilKit features while providing a good user experience in earlier versions of the OS that don’t support those features.

doc://com.apple.pencilkit/documentation/.title: Supporting backward compatibility for ink types

abstract.text: A view that allows the scrolling and zooming of its contained views.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
A type of focus item container that supports automatic scrolling of focusable content.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
